p: The evidence, however, also demonstrates that when traditional knowledge is valued and communities are involved as active participants, not as mere one-time consultants in order to ‘tick boxes’, projects can be remarkably successful as is witnessed by the Live & Learn Project carried out successfully in Temwaiku, South Tarawa [ 58]. In this project, the communities in Temwaiku collaborated on a joint food security project geared towards production of traditional foods of Kiribati and some non-indigenous foods. Every household was encouraged to have their own food garden as an adaptation to threats from climate change and food price volatility. This has provided some income, with part of the produce sold while significantly increasing the food security of the households involved.
